awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS: Institute for Foundations of Data Science (IFDS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to plant the seeds for an interdisciplinary institute devoted to foundations of data science at MIT. During the three years of Phase I, the project goal is to stimulate research and educational interactions between mathematics, statistics and theoretical computer science, both within MIT and in the research community at large. On the way, the team will also develop the organizational capabilities and visibility needed for the (potential) Phase II activities.

The project activities in Phase I will be organized around 5 semester-long themes. Each theme will be devoted to a topic at the intersection of at least two (and often three) TRIPODS areas, and will focus on catalyzing interactions between them. The specific themes are: statistical and computational tradeoffs, sub-linear algorithms and distribution testing, learning with complex structures, graphical models and exchangeability, and non-convex optimization. Within each theme, the PIs will organize numerous activities, including a workshop, a fall/spring school covering introductory material, and regular seminars. They will also support knowledge transfer activities, including office hours that will offer free help and consultation on algorithmic, mathematical and statistical aspects of data science. To facilitate the interactions between the participants, the project will support two project postdocs, who will play the role of connectors between different disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to plant the seeds of an interdisciplinary institute devoted to foundations of data science. The institute pursued research and educational interaction between mathematics, statistics and theoretical computer science, both within MIT and in the research community at large. Its additional goal was to develop organizational capabilities and visibility necessary to scale the activities to the Phase II of the TRIPODS program.

To this end, we established MIFODS, MIT Institute for Foundations of Data Science. MIFODS research and outreach activities were organized around semester-long themes. Each theme was devoted to a topic at the intersection of at least two TRIPODS areas and was focused on catalyzing interactions between them. During the semesters we organized several activities, including workshops, boot camps covering introductory material and regular seminars. In particular, we have organized 4 workshops covering the topics investigated in this project:

  • Sublinear algorithms, local algorithms and robust statistics (June 10-13, 2018)
  • Nonconvex optimization and deep learning (January 27-30, 2019)
  • Graphical models, exchangeable models and graphons (August 18-21, 2019)
  • Learning under complex structure (January 27-29, 2020)

To facilitate the interactions between members of MIFODS, the project funded multiple postdocs through competitive fellowships. These postdocs played the role of "connectors" between different disciplines. Furthermore, we organized "MIFODS overlay seminar", featuring talks presented in regular MIT seminar series. The talks were recorded and posted on the website and on a dedicated Youtube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/MIFODS), that has reached over 1.6K subscribers.

The aforementioned activities increased the interactions with other Boston-area institutions, whose faculty often participated in MIFODS events. In addition, we have established connections to another TRIPODS institute at UC Berkeley. The consortium of these institutions has been awarded TRIPODS Phase II award to establish a new institute called FODSI: Foundations of Data Science Institute.
